p: When the projection of the habitat suitability of P. caribaeorum for the present ( Fig.Â 3) is compared with the map of the biggest river discharges in the study area ( Fig. 1), it becomes evident that salinity has a major influence on the distribution of this species. Salinity had a higher contribution to the model, sometimes reducing habitat suitability even when the values of other variables, like temperature and chlorophyll- a, were adequate for the species. Freshwater discharges from rivers are also an important source of calcite for oceans; however, calcite is 100 times more soluble in seawater than in freshwater ( Libes, 2009), so high concentrations of this mineral are not limited to river-influenced regions. In fact, regarding only calcite, habitat suitability is positively correlated with its concentration, possibly because calcite concentration also indicates other important biogeochemical controls.
